title: Development of an Offline-Friend Addiction Questionnaire (O-FAQ): Are most people really social addicts? - Behavior Research Methods

last_post.content:
A fantastic way to make an important point. Researchers took items from widely-used scales of "social media addiction," and reworded them to be about spending time offline with friends. Using parallel criteria, they discovered that 69% of people are addicted to spending time with friends.

"Readers should approach our measure with a level of skepticism that should be afforded to current social media addiction measures."

(h/t @cconrymurray)

title: Disinvested: How Government and Private Industry Let the Main Street of a Black Neighborhood Crumble

last_post.content:
After a white gunman murdered MLK in 1968, riots broke out across the country.

In Chicago, it's widely said these riots are to blame for the acres of vacant land and the dearth of businesses on the West Side, where the riots started.

@ProPublica's 2020 investigation took a closer look at that claim.

We found other factors at play:
• Broken promises by gov't to rebuild
• Overzealous "blight removal" programs
• Rampant speculation by real estate investors

https://www.propublica.org/article/disinvested-how-government-and-private-industry-let-the-main-street-of-a-black-neighborhood-crumble

I think (thanks to a mastodon instance admin for looking at their logs!) that what happened is that my instance got slow, so some of the HTTP requests to my server timed out and failed. I think 3 possible fixes are:

1. wait 30 days & rerun the migration myself
2. ask my old instance to retry the migration, once it's running a release with this code https://github.com/mastodon/mastodon/pull/22330
3. instance admins can maybe manually retry failed jobs (seems like a lot to ask though)

h/t @nova for her work on this

title: Bringing informative priors into your experiment: Bayesian impact evaluation

last_post.content: For a long time I've wanted to try out Bayesian impact evaluation, by formally eliciting priors from policymakers, academics, and program recipients, and then incorporating these into the analysis. A new working paper with Rachael Meager and Leo Iacovone details how we did this with an export promotion program in Colombia, and shows when this gives similar results to frequentist analysis, and where it adds value. A blog summary (and link to the paper) is now up: https://blogs.worldbank.org/impactevaluations/bringing-informative-priors-your-experiment-bayesian-impact-evaluation

title: Negative affect increases reanalysis of conflicts between discourse context and world knowledge

last_post.content:
What do you do when you’re in a bad mood? You might use the time to tackle tasks that require analytical skills, like proofreading, a new study suggests.

Scientists tested people’s analytical skills when they were in good or bad moods.

“When people are in a negative mood, they are more careful and analytical. They scrutinize what's actually stated in a text, and they don't just fall back on their default world knowledge,” says U of Arizona researcher Vicky Lai.

https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fcomm.2022.910482/full

title: A Curious Integral | The n-Category Café

last_post.content:
Meckes is an expert on probability theory. His breakthrough came not here but on The n-Category Café, starting here:

https://golem.ph.utexas.edu/category/2023/01/a_curious_integral.html#c061933

and on until he says "Okay, here we go." He reduces the problem of showing

\[ \displaystyle{\frac{\pi}{8} - \int_0^\infty\cos(2x)\prod_{n=1}^\infty\cos\left(\frac{x}{n} \right) d x } \]

is small to the problem of showing it's improbable that the sum of certain random variables is bigger than 4. Then he uses Hoeffding's inequality!

(2/n)

title: Utriusque cosmi maioris scilicet et minoris metaphysica, physica atque technica historia ... [Tractatus secundus de naturae simia seu technica macrocosmi historia] / [Robert Fludd].

last_post.content:
You see a black square representing the nothingness that was prior to the universe. This square was printed with a wood block in Robert Fludd's "Utriusque cosmi maioris scilicet et minoris metaphysica..." (1617), and is framed by four sentences in Latin: "Et sic in infinitum". Fludd's pre-universe idea was aware of its visual limits of representation in a book. That's why all directions have a "And so on to infinity" remark.

Access the page: https://wellcomecollection.org/works/gbbychu2/images?id=gzy3gujm

#BookHistory #histodons
